text: today on times gassed thousands of
Greeks strike in the first protest since
June but many are disillusioned with
their campaign against the country's
austerity measures the Supreme Court
considers whether Picasso's paintings
and Alfred Hitchcock's films can be
returned to the public domain and
chronic homelessness declines in New
York City strikes are a common form of
protest in Greece but as the country
continues to scramble to avoid default
its protest culture has become
despondent this is Suzanne daily
reporting from Greece where the first
general strike since last spring took
place today and thousands of people came
out in front of Greeks Parliament's what
was interesting about today's strike is
it was not thousands of people screaming
with passion in pictures and videos it
can look like there are moments of
violence in truth is a very short-lived
little incidents the marchers themselves
seem bored and certainly the man on the
street doesn't even turn his head to
look at it anymore you can feel that
there is a sense of fatigue a weariness
it's been almost two years the news has
been unrelentingly bad Greece is hoping
to get its next eight billion euro loan
part of a hundred and ten billion euro
rescue package but even that it's just
stop gap measure and when they look down
the road all they see is more poverty
more austerity and no good news ahead
lawyers for orchestra conductors and
film archivist met before the Supreme
Court to have a copyright law overturned
the Supreme Court heard arguments
Wednesday morning in an important
copyright case that asks a very fresh
question does Congress have the power to
withdraw from the public domain more
than a million works including musical
compositions by Stravinsky in
Shostakovich paintings by Picasso movies
by hitchcock and Fellini novels by
Virginia Woolf and hg wells can those
works once in the public domain be
restored to copyright protection small
symphonies for
since our high school orchestras can no
longer perform works that had been part
of their standard repertoire is because
they can't afford the fees that now have
become attached to these works that have
been restored to copyright there were
more than the usual number of friend of
the court briefs filed and not always in
an obvious way Google for instance
supported the orchestra conductors and
others who want into law struck down and
Google of course is in the process of
compiling an enormous public domain
repository of books creators of content
and owners of content like movie studios
and so on were on the site of copyright
protection judging from the arguments
today it seems more likely than not that
the court will uphold the law and and
leave the high school orchestra
conductors looking for other works to
perform and New York City has seen a
sharp drop in the number of chronically
homeless thanks to a new transitional
housing program this used to be one of
the major homeless encampments in the
South Bronx under the major deegan
expressway it's an old abandoned train
platform there are tunnels running under
here where guys lived about five years
ago we reported on a guy named Johnny
Five who lived here and there were guys
who lived up on the platform and now
it's all dated off tactics like this and
in other places around the South Bronx
is the reason that there's been an 80%
to rob and individual homelessness and
in the borough the Department of
homeless services has opened safe haven
shelters around around town they're
smaller more private shelters with fewer
restrictions where people can come come
and go as they please and it's usually a
temporary step toward permanent housing
what's changed in the last couple of
years is that the city and we've taken
approach that's a housing first approach
meaning that individuals don't need to
be you know sober and clean to accept
services they don't need to be taking
their medication they don't need to be
psychiatrically stable there's an
understanding that let's first address
their homelessness and you know and then
we could start addressing some of the
more complicated issues in life the city
really struggled with street
homelessness for years and this new
model seems to be working one
sample is more of a shepherd who I spend
a lot of time with who the outreach
workers came back to again and again and
asked him to move inside and eventually
they were successful they moved him into
a safe haven shelter and now has been
now he's living in permanent housing and
he's been there for almost three years
my name is Marvin Shepherd this is my
apartment I actually lived on the street
for 10 years 10 odd years they would
come by on a daily basis two or three
times a day and give me options as to
what I could do to get off the streets
it didn't work right away but they wore
me down to eventually I realized that
these people really can help me and it
was time for me to change my life he is
sobered up he was he had been on the
streets for 10 years of using crack
cocaine he's reentered his family's
lives and then he seems to be doing
really well because I look at these
pictures pain this is the last thing
that I see when I walk out the door and
this is the first thing I see when I
come in and he's just a reminder to me
that if I take those back with steps I'm
going to be out of her life and back on
the street and I can't allow that to
happen
